prompt.p: A 20-year-old woman presents with polyuria and thirst. Urine dipstick is negative for ketones and glucose. Blood tests reveal a low plasma sodium of 130 mmol/l (normal range 135–145 mmol/l). Blood glucose is normal. A water deprivation test improves her polyuria.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option C is Correct. See Targeted Learning for further information.
Option A is Incorrect. This normally causes hypernatraemia.
Option B is Incorrect. Glucose can induce an osmotic diuresis and cause polyuria. Normal blood and urinary glucose would make this diagnosis unlikely.

Option D is Incorrect. This can cause hyponatraemia by causing syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). SIADH would not cause polyuria, and a water deprivation test would not improve this symptom.
Option E is Incorrect. UTI causes urinary frequency but not polyuria. Also, urine dipstick is negative.
